Dominic Heale 
Update: November 19, 2021

title: Barefoot path and bathing pond
short_description: Who can balance on tree stumps or walk on pine cones without shoes?
long_description: From the Café Extra, we put our shoes in our rucksacks and start walking barefoot. First we walk across the meadow, then into the forest. Again and again there are stations where we can test our skills. Who can balance over tree stumps without shoes or run over pine cones? And who dares to go through the mud hole? At the end of the tour, a jump into the Kirnbergsee is tempting - after all, we want clean feet again!

title: Șoseaua Transalpina
short_description:
Transalpina, drumul național 67C, este probabil cea mai frumoasă șosea din România. Drumul  traversează Munții Parâng, făcând legătura între localitățile Sebeș (jud. Alba) și Novaci (jud. Gorj). Este șoseaua la cea mai mare altitudine din țară, atinsă în Pasul Urdele (2145m).
Translate to English
long_description:
Transalpina a devenit un obiectiv turistic în sine după modernizarea segmentului din golul alpin, între Obârșia Lotrului și Rânca. Până atunci, șoseaua exista, dar în stare precară.
Astăzi, sub orice formă ai parcurge segmentul alpin - cu mașina, cu motorul sau cu bicicleta - e imposibil să nu te treacă puțin fiorii la fiecare viraj, când în dreapta nu ai parapet. Din fericire, îți poți trage sufletul și inspira aerul tăios de munte prin opriri pe marginea drumului. Peisajele sunt spectaculoase!
Transalpina reprezintă, de fapt, un vechi drum militar, considerat strategic, de legătură între Muntenia și Transilvania. Totodată, Transalpina este și vechiul drum de trashumanță al ciobanilor care treceau cu oile dintr-o regiune în alta.
Porțiunea asfaltată recent, totodată și cea mai spectaculoasă, era cunoscută sub denumirea Drumul Regelui. În perioada interbelică, la ordinul Regelui Carol al II-lea, porțiunea a fost refăcută, tot din rațiuni militare.
La fel ca alte drumuri transmontane din țară, Transalpina este închisă pe perioada iernii pe segmentul de gol alpin. 
Translate to English

images.caption: Transalpina, unul din cele mai frumoase trasee de motocicletă

title: Via Alpina: Riale - Ulrichen
long_description:
In 2002, the Alpine countries agreed to create a long-distance hiking trail through the Alps, the Via Alpina from Trieste to Monaco. It became a network of trails. This stage is part of the "Red Trail", the main trail of the Via Alpina.

Stage Riale - Ulrichen
After the short detour to Piedmont, we will leave Italy again today and return to Switzerland. After hearing German and Romansh as well as Italian in Switzerland, the language spoken in the lower part of the now following canton of Valais is predominantly French. However, we come to the uppermost part of the Valais, the Goms, where German is spoken. However, the local dialect takes some getting used to, even for German-speaking Swiss. Today's route is designated "Via Sbrinz (40)" and is a reminder that Sbrinz, the hard cheese produced in central Switzerland, used to be exported mainly to northern Italy, over the Grimsel and then along our present path.
On our way into the Valle di Morasco we first come to the Lago di Morasco reservoir, but at the far end of the reservoir we already come to the end of the valley, we climb along the northern flank of the Rio del Gries into the Valle del Gries up to the Passo del Griess or Griespass. Here we leave Italy and are welcomed into Switzerland with a beautiful view of the Gries glacier and the artificial Gries lake.
At the dam, the view opens up into the valley and we see the road to the Nufenen pass, which winds up in serpentines. After we then meet the pass road further down, we will share the narrow valley floor through the Ägene valley even with the Ägene and the road until we reach the valley of the young Rhône at Ulrichen, which is still called the "Rotte" here in the Goms, however.

title: Via Alpina: Ulrichen - Fieschertal
long_description:
In 2002, the Alpine countries agreed to create a long-distance hiking trail through the Alps, the Via Alpina from Trieste to Monaco. It became a network of trails. This stage is part of the "Red Trail", the main trail of the Via Alpina.

The Ulrichen - Fieschertal stage
This stage leads through the Valais towards Lake Geneva, i.e. down the valley. That sounds like a relaxed hike - so this stage can be a little longer than the previous ones. However, the trail architects do not simply lead us along the "Rotte", but want to show us the landscape from above today as well - so we hike along the "Gommer Höhenweg". To divide up the route, it is best to orientate ourselves on the side valleys and their streams that we cross. This not only adds kilometres, but also a few metres in altitude thanks to the steep side valleys - so in the end we still have a nourishing Via Alpina stage ahead of us, even without high passes.
First we climb up the northern flank of the valley at Ulrichen until we meet the Gommer Höhenweg at Bine, and we then follow these signposts to Bellwald. Then there is a descent to Fiesch, followed by another ascent and descent in the Fieschertal valley to the village of the same name.

title: Via Alpina: Capanna d'Efra - Sonogno
short_description: In 2002, the Alpine countries agreed to create a long-distance hiking trail through the Alps, the Via Alpina, from Trieste to Monaco. It became a network of paths. This stage is part of the Red Trail, the main route of the Via Alpina.
long_description:
Today's stage is another short one with practically no climbs, but almost exclusively a descent, although not as steep as the recent descent to Biasca.

First we descend from the hut to Lago d´Efra, which we can already see from the start. Then we follow the outlet of this lake, the Riale d'Efra, northwest. However, we do not follow the Riale directly downwards, but make a wide bend over the Alpe dell'Efra to finally descend on the sunny side to Chignolo, where we meet the stream again. We now follow the stream out of the Val d'Efra until we meet the Verzasca at Frasco, which gave the main valley its name. Now there are just a few flat kilometres to the stage town of Sonogno.

title: Via Alpina: Fontana - Robièi
long_description:
In 2002, the Alpine countries agreed to create a long-distance hiking trail through the Alps, the Via Alpina from Trieste to Monaco. It became a network of trails. This stage is part of the "Red Trail", the main trail of the Via Alpina.

Stage Fontana - Robièi
Today's hike through the Val Bavona starts out quite flat, but from San Carlo onwards the ascent to the Robièi reservoir becomes steadily steeper. Our path to today's stage point is signalled as "Sentiero Cristallina (59)". The valley is characterised by steep mountain flanks, by a series of rustic hamlets and also by historic dwellings built into rock cavities. At Foroglio, we will remember a 50-metre-high waterfall. From San Carlo, the route then climbs in narrow serpentines up to the Robièi reservoir in a rocky basin - the accommodation is slightly below the reservoir.

title: Highlights of the Nagelfluhkette
short_description: Exposed ridges, wild waterfalls and gentle alpine pastures - experience the whole diversity of the Nagelfluhkette Nature Park on a challenging mountain hike.
long_description: More highlights can hardly be packed into a single day's hike: The adventurous ridge traverse of the Nagelfluhkette brings us, partly secured by wire ropes, to the panoramic peaks of Steineberg and Stuiben. A leisurely descent is followed by a well-deserved break at the alpine dairy, before we descend through mountain forests and alpine meadows to the Alpsee. The Mittagbahn cable car saves us a strenuous ascent at the beginning, so that we can tackle the ridge hike with fresh legs. For the first half of the tour, it is essential to be sure-footed and have a head for heights. Those who do not dare to climb the long ladder to the Steineberg and the exposed summit ridge to the Stuiben can, however, avoid both.

images.caption: Auf dem Weg vom Mittag zum Steineberg

title: Via Alpina: Prato - Fontana
long_description:
In 2002, the Alpine countries agreed to create a long-distance hiking trail through the Alps, the Via Alpina from Trieste to Monaco. It became a network of trails. This stage is part of the "Red Trail", the main trail of the Via Alpina.

Stage Prato - Fontana
This stage takes us from Prato in Val Lavizzara to Fontana in Val Bavone. The mountain river Bavone is also a feeder of the Maggia. We first climb southwards on the right bank of the Maggia to the sun terrace Monti di Rima. There we turn north and climb counter-clockwise steadily around Pizzo di Brünesc, which we come closest to when we cross the Bochetta di Fiorasca culmination point. We then descend steeply again via Alpe Fiorasca to the stage town of Fontana.

title: Maasduinen walking route
short_description: When you see the name and the location of this nature reserve, you will be surprised for a moment, because after all, dunes are by the sea. Around the Maas in Limburg, dunes have also been created by the moving water.
long_description:
The Maasduinen is a beautiful walking area. You can enjoy the peace and nature. The sheep in the area keep the heathland in order. Furthermore you can see cranes.
De Maasduinen consists of beautiful woods, dunes, fens, fields, meadows and sand plains.

images.caption: The fens of the Maasduinen nature reserve

title: Pigeon Breast Stone Trail
short_description: In a region full of waterfalls, the trail that leads to the top of Pedra do Peito do Pombo has a peculiar rocky formation and an incredible view.
long_description:
At first, it is a very clean trail and a pleasant contact with nature, shaded by the Atlantic Forest and with some farms inhabited and cultivated by residents of that region and has as means of access this old path. Today the area is protected as a permanent preservation area, but in the midst of all this there are cattle pastures which leave the trail exposed to the sun in certain stretches. It borders the waters of a waterfall that comes down from the hills.
The greatest difficulty é after crossing the waterfall and heading towards Peito do Pombo, as this final climb é quite íngrime and through the middle of the forest. After 40 minutes to 1 hour of walking in the forest, there is the base of the rock, and going around it to the right, you can climb the rock in front or, following a few more meters, find the rope to climb the slab where there are in fact two rocks that resemble a pigeon.

images.caption: Pedra do Peito do Pombo, Macaé
Pedra do Peito do Pombo, Macaé

title: Scandiberian
short_description: The Scandibérique is the French section of EuroVelo 3, a route linking Norway to Santiago de Compostela in Spain.
long_description:
Stretching over 1700 km, La Scandibérique crosses 20 départements, 4 regions and major cities such as Paris and Bordeaux.
This varied route offers a complete experience, passing through plains and hills, towpaths, state-owned forests, moors, places steeped in history, historic towns and bastides, as well as unspoilt natural areas, right up to the Pyrenees mountains.
The diversity of landscapes promises a full range of sensations.

title: Ajusco summits and Pico del Aquila peak
short_description: Challenging route to the summit of the Ajusco Volcano, almost 4,000 metres high, passing the Pico del Aquila with an incredible view.
long_description: This route also starts at the alpine lodge at 3,280 metres above sea level and follows part of the previous route, although it continues through the gap until you reach the old cabin, from where you start to take a path that connects with the ridge that leads directly to the Pico del Aquila. This route has a difference in altitude of 680 metres, as to reach the Marqués cross you first climb the Pico del Aquila, descending towards the pass before reaching the summit of Ajusco. This route has a distance of 4.5km. The route goes to the north summit of Ajusco up to 3,500 metres above sea level and from there on the terrain is mostly rocky.

title: Via Alpina C12: Griesalp - Kandersteg
short_description: In 2002, the Alpine countries agreed to create a long-distance hiking trail through the Alps, the Via Alpina, from Trieste to Monaco. It became a network of paths. These stages from Liechtenstein to Montreux belong to the «Great Way».

title: Via Alpina C11: Lauterbrunnen - Griesalp
short_description: In 2002, the Alpine countries agreed to create a long-distance hiking trail through the Alps, the Via Alpina, from Trieste to Monaco. It became a network of paths. These stages from Liechtenstein to Montreux belong to the «Great Way».

title: Via Alpina C14: Adelboden - Lenk
short_description: In 2002, the Alpine countries agreed to create a long-distance hiking trail through the Alps, the Via Alpina, from Trieste to Monaco. It became a network of paths. These stages from Liechtenstein to Montreux belong to the «Great Way».
long_description:
This one crosses 14 of the most beautiful Alpine passes. Across 6 Swiss cantons and the Principality of Liechtenstein, we encounter diverse culture, geology and topography. Wide roads end in airy ridge paths. One of the world's most diverse flora and fauna line the path. Quiet periods of relaxation alternate with prosperous tourist resorts. The ultra-modern alp with pipelines and its showroom is on the way, as is the alpine pasture where pigs, goats and cows watch the farmers at work. Displacements, shifts, subsidences and rock erosions bear witness to interestingly structured geology. Breathtaking panoramas alternate with small curiosities along the way and the gastronomy offers a variety of delicacies.

The Adelboden - Lenk
stage
We leave Adelboden, which lies at the beginning of the «Entschlige», heading southwest, first along the Entschlige feeder «Allebach», and a little later along the Gilsbach (later also Geilsbach) coming from Süden. The ascent to the Hahnenmoospass then begins at Geilsbühl, which we cover along a road.
Through moorland and later also forests, we then continue on footpaths from the pass to the stage destination of Lenk in the rear Simmental. On this route we can enjoy impressive waterfalls and the view of the Wildstrubel massif to the south of our route.

title: Via Alpina C9: Meiringen - Grindelwald
short_description: In 2002, the Alpine countries agreed to create a long-distance hiking trail through the Alps, the Via Alpina, from Trieste to Monaco. It became a network of paths. These stages from Liechtenstein to Montreux belong to the «Great Way».
long_description:
This one crosses 14 of the most beautiful Alpine passes. Across 6 Swiss cantons and the Principality of Liechtenstein, we encounter diverse culture, geology and topography. Wide roads end in airy ridge paths. One of the world's most diverse flora and fauna line the path. Quiet periods of relaxation alternate with prosperous tourist resorts. The ultra-modern alp with pipelines and its showroom is on the way, as is the alpine pasture where pigs, goats and cows watch the farmers at work. Displacements, shifts, subsidences and rock erosions bear witness to interestingly structured geology. Breathtaking panoramas alternate with small curiosities along the way and the gastronomy offers a variety of delicacies.

Stage Meiringen - Grindelwald
Shortly after the start we cross the young Aare and arrive via Willigen at the Reichenbachfällen, which thanks to Sherlock Holmes became famous beyond the country's borders. The first 400 metres uphill are quite steep, but then the gradient eases and we hike along the Reichenbach valley to Rosenlaui, cross the Gletcherschlucht gorge at the foot of the «Klein Wellhorn» on the left, then the view opens up to the Grosse Scheidegg and the Wetterhorn to the south.
At the foot of the Wetterhorn, the route then descends pleasantly to the stage town of Grindelwald. There are no surprises to be feared on this stage, as it mostly runs close to the road from Meiringen to Grindelwald, which is also used by postbuses.

title: Via Alpina: Selma - Alpe di Cava
Via Alpina: Pian San Giacomo - Selma
Via Alpina: Alpe di Cava - Biasca
short_description: In 2002, the Alpine countries agreed to create a long-distance hiking trail through the Alps, the Via Alpina, from Trieste to Monaco. It became a network of paths. This stage is part of the Red Trail, the main route of the Via Alpina.
long_description:
This stage is quite short at around 10 kilometres, especially if it only offers about 150 metres of ascent at the same time. However, once you reach the Forcorella di Lago south-west of the Capanna Cava, you still have the part ahead of you that we will remember from this stage, almost 2000 metres of steep descent across alpine pastures and through forests to the stage town of Biasca, with rocky outcrops above and below our path!
Biasca lies on the main axis from Switzerland to Italy, the best known being the Gotthard Pass and the corresponding railway line, and there is also traffic from the Valais over the Nufenen Pass, and the Ticino river also starts at the Nufenen Pass. These two axes come together at Airolo. In Biasca, the traffic coming from the Grisons via the Lukmanier Pass is added in the direction of the south, along the Brenno mountain river.

title: Via Alpina: Rochers de Naye - Montreux
short_description: In 2002, the Alpine countries agreed to create a long-distance hiking trail through the Alps, the Via Alpina, from Trieste to Monaco. It became a network of paths. These stages from Liechtenstein to Montreux belong to the «Great Way».

title: Via Alpina: L'Etivaz - Rochers de Naye
Via Alpina: Isola - Pian San Giacomo
Via Alpina: Tirano - Poschiavo
short_description: In 2002, the Alpine countries agreed to create a long-distance hiking trail through the Alps, the Via Alpina from Trieste to Monaco. It became a whole network of trails. This stage from Tirano in the Italian Valtellina to Poschiavo in the Swiss Val Poschiavo is part of the "Red Trail", the main trail of the Via Alpina.
long_description:
This stage of the Via Alpina takes us from Tirano in the Italian Veltlin through the Val Poschiavo up towards the Bernina Pass to the main town of the Puschlav - the urban-looking Poschiavo. We do not follow the mountain stream "Poschiavino" like the main road and the Rhaetian Railway, but a historic mule track on the eastern flank of the valley. This path, signposted "Via Valtellina", runs high above the valley floor below an alpine ridge on which we find such melodious mountain peaks and crossings as Monte Masuccio, Cima da li Gandi Rossi, Piz Trevisina, Piz di Sassiglion or the Passo di Malghera. This alpine ridge corresponds to the border between Italy and Switzerland.
The climb starts quite steeply, 400 metres of altitude in less than 2 kilometres, and brings us first to the characteristic village of Roncaiola, which is still served by a road. From Roncaiola we have a magnificent view of Tirano, the Valtellina and the surrounding mountains. Above the rock face "Sasso del Gal" we next cross the Italian-Swiss border, which runs here from Tirano up to the aforementioned Alpine ridge. In this area we will not only encounter the Italian and German languages, but also Romansh, the 4th national language of Switzerland, which still survives in the canton of Graubünden. In the highest part of this stage, we will still pass through the picturesque alpine settlement of San Romerio high above Brusio, before the descent to the stage town of Poschiavo begins.

title: Via Alpina: Campo Moro - Chiareggio
short_description: In 2002, the Alpine countries agreed to create a long-distance hiking trail through the Alps, the Via Alpina from Trieste to Monaco. It became a network of trails. This stage from Campo Moro to Chiareggio is part of the "Red Trail", the main route of the Via Alpina.
long_description: This stage runs entirely on Italian soil. From the Zoia hut in Campo Moro, we reach the first culmination of this stage in the province of Sondrio in the Italian region of Lombardy, namely Alpe Musella, followed by a descent to Alp Capascio to tackle the ascent to Passo Campolungo, the highest point of today's stage. We reach Lago Palù via Alpe Palù and then descend into the Malenco valley with the Màllero stream. On the north side of this valley we hike with a moderate uphill and downhill slope to the stage town of Chiareggio.

title: Via Alpina: Poschiavo - Campo Moro
short_description: In 2002, the Alpine countries agreed to create a long-distance hiking trail through the Alps, the Via Alpina from Trieste to Monaco. It became a network of trails. This stage from Poschiavo to Campo Moro is part of the "Red Trail", the main trail of the Via Alpina.
long_description:
On the previous stage we crossed the border between Italy and Switzerland from the south and then had it to the east of our route on an Alpine ridge; today we will cross this national border again, to the west. So the Puschlav is surrounded by Italy on three sides.
We start the hike with a long ascent southwards and then gradually turn westwards. Through a forest we reach the Selva plateau. From here, the mountain trail leads us to the Pass da Cancian, where we then re-enter Italy, in the province of Sondrio in the Lombardy region. Over the Passo di Campagneda, which follows shortly afterwards, we come across beautiful alpine pastures to the Alp Campagneda, where we encounter a number of beautiful mountain lakes in flatter terrain. Passing the Rifugio Cristina, we reach the stage town of Campo Moro, which lies on the Lago di Campo Moro reservoir, south of the larger Lago di Gera reservoir. Campo Moro can be reached from Italy on a road.

title: Kust till Kustleden - from Torekov to Gryteskär
short_description: The penultimate stage of the Kust till Kustleden leads from the village of Torekov along the beach to the Gryteskär campsite.
long_description: Before we leave, we can take a short trip from Torekov harbour to Hallands V island. On this leg, too, we walk leisurely along the beach. Our route takes us past idyllic fishing villages where sea seals sun themselves on the rocks;

title: Crossing Tennengebirge - along | Abtenau - Stegenwald
short_description: Longitudinal crossing of the Tennengebirge (east to west) - from Abtenau to Stegenwald
long_description:
This very beautiful, panoramic and absolutely little hiked tour leads in 2-3 day stages through the breathtaking mountain world of the Tennengebirge.  The longitudinal traverse of the rugged mountain massif begins in Abtenau and leads over 5 peaks (Bleikogl, Mittleres Streitmandl, Hiefler, Raucheck and Hühnerkrallkopf) to Stegenwald.
The route initially leads through forests and then soon changes to wild rugged karst areas. For the most part, you are at an altitude of over 2000 metres and are rewarded with fantastic views of the Salzach Valley, the Hohe Tauern and the Hochkönig on the opposite side.
The route leads through forests in the beginning and then soon into wild, craggy karst areas.

images.caption: Mountain tour in the Tennen Mountains: Crossing Tennengebirge - längs | Abtenau - Stegenwald

title: Nordic Walking Route to Bachtelsee
short_description: The walking tour along the Wertach not only opens up beautiful views of the Bärensee and Bachtelsee lakes - with a little luck you can also observe beavers.
long_description: The easy tour runs on flat, mostly well-maintained paths and takes about 1.5 hours.

title: Via Alpina C4: Elm - Linthal
long_description:
In 2002, the Alpine countries agreed to create a long-distance hiking trail through the Alps, the Via Alpina from Trieste to Monaco. It became a network of paths. These stages from Liechtenstein to Montreux belong to the «Great Way».
This ücrosses 14 of the most beautiful Alpine passes. Across 6 Swiss cantons and the Principality of Liechtenstein, we encounter diverse culture, geology and topography. Wide roads end in airy ridge paths. One of the world's most diverse flora and fauna line the path. Quiet periods of relaxation alternate with prosperous tourist resorts. The ultra-modern alp with pipelines and its showroom is on the way, as is the alpine pasture where pigs, goats and cows watch the farmers at work. Displacements, shifts, subsidences and rock erosions bear witness to interestingly structured geology. Breathtaking panoramas alternate with small beauty spots along the way and the gastronomy has a variety of delicacies in store.

Etappe Elm - Linthal
The southern part of the canton of Glarus is characterised by the Sernf and Linth rivers and their valleys, which come together at Schwanden. The starting point Elm is on the Sernf, the stage point Linthal on the Linth.
We leave Elm, which lies in the GeoPark, where the formation of the Alps with the «Glarner Hauptüberschiebung becomes visible, in a westerly direction. We then climb steadily along the flank of the Schabell, with ski lifts and cable cars showing us that we are in an area used intensively for tourism.
From «Unter Ampächli» the gradient gradually eases and we then hike in a south-westerly direction. Only at the Obererbs ski hut does the gradient increase again and leads us past the Erbser Stock through a hollow to the highest point of the day, the Richetlipass. Over a series of alpine pastures through the lonely Durnachtal valley, we then hike in a relaxed manner downhill to the stage town of Linthal and have remained in the canton of Glarus all day.

title: Via Alpina: Juf - Innerferrera
long_description:
In 2002, the Alpine countries agreed to create a long-distance hiking trail through the Alps, the Via Alpina from Trieste to Monaco. It became a network of trails. This stage is part of the "Red Trail", the main trail of the Via Alpina.

Stage Juf - Innerferrera
Today's stage is practically a rest day for long-distance hikers on the Via Alpina. Stages shorter than 20 kilometres are a common occurrence. But the fact that the ascent is only about 100 metres is an exception, because today we are walking downhill along the waters.
Along the Avers Rhine we hike westwards through the high valley of Avers, first on the road, then on hiking trails. The trail is signposted as the "Walserweg". At Cröt, the Avers Rhine is joined by the Madris Rhine from the left. Later, also from the left, on a ridge, the border with Italy comes closer and closer to our path. Behind this ridge lies the long reservoir "Lago da Lei", whereby Lago and Lei mean the same thing, namely "lake", once in Italian, once in Romansh. Italy is only a few kilometres wide in this valley over there, whereby at the height of Campsut the border makes a detour from the crest - which precisely only includes the dam wall. Now the valley becomes narrower and the mountain flanks steeper. At the "Punt di Val di Lei", this Italian tip of land ends right next to our route and brings more water. Shortly afterwards, we arrive at the stage stop Innerferrera.

title: Via Alpina C6: Urner Boden - Altdorf
short_description: In 2002, the Alpine countries agreed to create a long-distance hiking trail through the Alps, the Via Alpina, from Trieste to Monaco. It became a network of paths. These stages from Liechtenstein to Montreux belong to the «Great Way».
long_description:
This one crosses 14 of the most beautiful Alpine passes. Across 6 Swiss cantons and the Principality of Liechtenstein, we encounter diverse culture, geology and topography. Wide roads end in airy ridge paths. One of the world's most diverse flora and fauna line the path. Quiet periods of relaxation alternate with prosperous tourist resorts. The ultra-modern alp with pipelines and its showroom is on the way, as is the alpine pasture where pigs, goats and cows watch the farmers at work. Displacements, shifts, subsidences and rock erosions bear witness to interestingly structured geology. Breathtaking panoramas alternate with small curiosities along the way and the gastronomy has a variety of delicacies in store.

Stage Linthal - Urner Boden
We leave the Urner Boden uphill towards the Klausenpass, i.e. in a westerly direction. We walk along the old pass path and cross today's main road a few times, sometimes from below, sometimes from above, and for a short time we even walk right next to the road.
From the pass we follow a high trail past the Heidmanegg and enjoy the Alpine panorama that the Schächental offers us. Behind Mettenen the steep descent begins to Spiringen, where we rejoin the main road at the bottom of the valley. Passing Bürglen, we reach the «Tell-Info-Weg» to the stage town of Altdorf, where this stage ends at the Tell monument on the town hall square, here is the symbolic cradle of Switzerland.

title: Kuskovo Forest Park invites you for a walk!
short_description: A cosy, clean park at Kuskovo Manor for walks and gatherings. The park's greenery — is the guarantor of fresh air and a welcoming mood for all visitors who cross its boundaries.
long_description:
Kuskovskiy Lesopark or the 17th century natural garden is part of the Sheremetev estate, which became a museum-reserve in 1919. Now the wooded area serves as a place for walks for city residents. The area features recreational complexes such as the Glade of Brides and ponds with boat rentals.
The park also has a great vantage point around the pond at the main facade of the manor house. The views of nature intertwined with the unique picture structure are freezing.

images.caption: Вид с пруда на музей-заповедник Кусково
Вид с пруда на Усадьба Кусково

title: Via Alpina C5: Linthal - Urner Boden
short_description: In 2002, the Alpine countries agreed to create a long-distance hiking trail through the Alps, the Via Alpina, from Trieste to Monaco. It became a network of paths. These stages from Liechtenstein to Montreux belong to the «Great Way».

title: Via Alpina: Maloja - Juf
short_description: In 2002, the Alpine countries agreed to create a long-distance hiking trail through the Alps, the Via Alpina, from Trieste to Monaco. It became a network of paths. This stage from Maloja to Juf is part of the «Red Trail», the main trail of the Via Alpina.
long_description:
We walk eastwards for a few 100 metres on the main road and then leave it to the left, heading uphill. At Plan di Zoch we are joined by an elevated path marked «Senda Segantini (25)», which is identical to our stage until the Septimerpass.
The climb does not allow us to take a breather until we reach a depression at Lake Lunghin - we have reached the beginning of the Inn, which will flow into the Danube as an impressive mountain river at Passau. Shortly afterwards we will reach the Lunghin Pass, with Piz Lunghin on our left. The short detour there is worthwhile, as it offers a breathtaking view into the Bergell.
&Uml;über die weiteren Pässe Septimer (already used in Römer times) und Forcellina, und knapp unter dem Fuorcle da la Valletta vorbei kommen wir steil hinunter ins Tal des «Juferrheins», wo wir dann bald auf die 30-Seelen-Siedlung Juf stoßen. Juf at 2226 m.ü.m. claims to be the highest year-round inhabited settlement in Switzerland or even in the whole of Europe. With an inn and a tourist camp, Juf is a popular starting point for hikes and ski tours in summer and winter.

images.caption: Wanderung im Kanton Graubünden: Via Alpina: Maloja - Juf

title: Via Alpina: Chiareggio - Maloja
short_description: In 2002, the Alpine countries agreed to create a long-distance hiking trail through the Alps, the Via Alpina, from Trieste to Monaco. It became a network of paths. This stage from Chiareggio in Italy to Maloja in Switzerland is part of the Red Trail, the main route of the Via Alpina.
long_description:
From Chiareggio we continue to follow the Màllero stream uphill, past the Alpe dell'Oro, to its headwaters between Monte del Forno and Monte dell'Oro, where we cross the Passo del Muretto. On the other side, the trail continues downhill through the Val Muretto until it joins the Val Forno at Plan Cann. Along the Ortegna stream we reach the picturesque Cavloc Lake (with restaurant), a popular family excursion destination from Maloja. Shortly before the town of Maloja, we reach the Maloja Pass on the pass road, a pass that only has an ascent on the west side, but continues on the east side along the Upper Engadine lakes via St. Moritz along the young Inn River. From the car park on the pass we have an impressive view down into Bergell.
On the ascent we followed the Màllero flowing southwest and the Ortegna stream flowing northwest. However, the two waters will meet again in Lake Como and then flow together via the Po to the Adriatic Sea - we will cross the watershed between the Adriatic Sea and the Inn, which flows via the Danube into the Black Sea, on foot on the Maloja Pass.

title: Walenstöcke-Umrundung ab Brunnihütte
short_description:
Die Umrundung der Walenstöcke ist ein anspruchsvoller Klassiker für erfahrene Bergwanderer mit sehr guter Kondition. Eine Übernachtung in der Rugghubelhütte kann die Tour entzerren und für mehr Genuss sorgen. Egal, ob an einem oder zwei Tagen – die atemberaubende Kulisse und die Abwechslung entlang der Route machen diese Tour zu einem unvergesslichen Erlebnis.
Translate to English
long_description:
Ich starte meine Tour früh am Morgen bei der Brunnihütte, um die Walenstöcke zu umrunden – eine beeindruckende und anspruchsvolle Bergtour, die viel Kondition und Ausdauer verlangt. Die ersten Sonnenstrahlen begleiten mich auf dem Weg in Richtung Rugghubelhütte. Der anfängliche Anstieg durch saftige Alpwiesen und vorbei an Felswänden ist moderat und bietet fantastische Ausblicke ins Engelberger Tal.
Nach etwa zwei Stunden erreiche ich die Rugghubelhütte (2290 m ü. M.), die sich hervorragend für eine kleine Pause eignet. Für diejenigen, die sich die Tour in zwei Etappen aufteilen möchten, ist dies auch ein idealer Übernachtungsort. Ich jedoch entscheide mich, die gesamte Runde an einem Tag zu bewältigen.
Von der Rugghubelhütte führt der Weg weiter hinauf über Geröllfelder und steilere Passagen, bis ich den Übergang beim Rotgrätli (2572 m ü. M.) erreiche. Der Anblick der umliegenden Gipfel ist schlicht atemberaubend. Hier genieße ich eine kurze Rast und tanke Energie für den langen Abstieg.
Der Weg hinunter führt zunächst steil bergab über steinige Pfade, bevor ich durch die grünen Hänge zurück in Richtung Bannalp gelange. Die letzten Kilometer erfordern nochmals volle Konzentration und gute Trittsicherheit, besonders bei feuchtem Untergrund. Zurück nach Engelberg resp. zur Brunnihütte geht es über den Walenpfad. Nach insgesamt acht Stunden – erschöpft, aber glücklich – komme ich wieder bei der Brunnihütte an.
Translate to English

images.caption: Aussicht von der Walegg durchs Engelbergertal.
Fast senkrecht scheint der Blick zur Bannalp hinunterzufallen.
Atmeberaubend - Der Blick auf den Walenstock

title: From Göttelfingen to the Nagold reservoir
short_description: You hike through the forest on wide paths to the Nagold reservoir, which is a popular destination for outdoor activities of all kinds. You walk along the north bank via the Kropfmühle mill back to Göttelfingen.
long_description: The starting point of our hiking tour is the Rotlenswasen forest car park northwest of Göttelfingen. We follow the yellow rhombus and the signposting "V3" downwards through the forest to the north-western end of the Nagold reservoir. Now we walk along the northern shore of the lake. We follow the blue rhombus to the dam wall 3 km away. After 15 minutes we reach the covered wooden bridge where the main lake begins. Two kilometres later we reach the dam wall. On slightly sloping, gravelled paths we reach the Kropfmühle, a welcome refreshment stop. There is an altitude difference of almost 200 m to overcome to Göttelfingen. The yellow rhombus leads us directly to the church in the centre of the village. We follow the yellow rhombus zigzagging out of the village, past the sports facility and back to the Rotlenswasen forest car park.

images.caption: The Nagoldtalsperre offers many recreational opportunities.
From the covered wooden bridge we have a good view of the dam.

title: Bettlach - Tavannes
long_description:
The starting point of this long tour is in Allmend near Bettlach. The first 4 kilometres are a steep climb of 900 metres up to Grenchenberg. You first pass through the forest to the first clearing at Bettlacherberg. Via the steep Ängloch you climb up to the finishing point of this tour, Grenchenberg, where you have already reached the highest point of this tour. Then you continue more or less flat in a south-westerly direction for about 10 kilometres across the Montoz plain. Through the Forêt du Montez you descend to Tavannes, the end point of this route.

Note(s)
- Very good physical condition required
- Sufficient snow
- Also feasible as a 2-day tour (bivouac equipment!)
- If possible, follow existing tracks

.

title: Stage 01 of the European Valley Circuit
short_description: The first stage of the European Valley Circuit takes walkers through the Santa Catarina cities of Indaial, Rodeio and Timbó. The beautiful landscapes of the region are also full of history, with several typical German buildings.
long_description:
The European Valley Circuit was created to take its visitors through the various cultural and natural tourist attractions of the region. There are 200 km of dirt roads in beautiful rural areas of 9 cities. The circuit is all self-guided, signposted with white arrows on posts and stones, as well as having information boards along the way.
Don't miss the accreditation of the Circuit, in the Hotel Fink in the city of Indaial, to receive your passport and a booklet with information about the whole route, at a cost of R$ 20,00. The passport can be stamped in several places and when the Circuit has been completed, é possible to withdraw a certificate in the same place of accreditation.
The first stage of the Circuit begins in Indaial. Start by visiting the Casarão Café Coworking, the city's historic building, and continue to the Ponte dos Arcos. Along the way, there are museums, churches and old houses built in enxaimel, as well as a beautiful rural landscape. In the city of Timbó, take some time to visit the Museum of Music and Immigrant, as well as the Henry Paul Park and the House of Arts and Crafts, at Praça Frederico Donner.

images.caption: Museu da Música em Timbó, Santa Catarina - Brasil
Ponte no Complexo Turístico Jardim do Imigrante em Timbó, Santa Catarina - Brasil
Represa no Complexo Turístico Jardim do Imigrante em Timbó, Santa Catarina - Brasil
Casa do Artesão em Timbó, Santa Catarina - Brasil

title: सतोपंथ ताल ट्रैक, उत्तराखंड, भारत
short_description: सतोपंथ ताल उत्तराखंड के चमोली जिले में 15100 फीट की ऊँ चाई पर स्थित है। यह गढ़वाल हिमालय की बर्फी ली चोटियों और विशाल ग्लेशियरों से घिरी हुई एक साफ़ अनछु ई ग्लैसिअल झील है।
long_description:
सतोपंथ ताल एक त्रिकोणीय आकार की अल्पाइन झील है जो बद्रीनाथ तीर्थ के पास स्थित है। धार्मिक महत्व के अलावा, सतोपंथ ताल ट्रैक हाल के वर्षों में तेजी से उत्तराखंड के सबसे लोकप्रिय ट्रैक में से एक बन गया है।
सतोपंथ झील का इतिहास बहुत समृद्ध है। ऐसा माना जाता है कि भगवान ब्रह्मा, विष्णु, शिव ने इसके तीन कोनों पर ध्यान किया था। इस झील के निकट कई ग्लेशियरों के बीच "स्वर्गारोहिणी" नाम का एक ग्लेशियर है जिसका शाब्दिक अर्थ "स्वर्ग को ले जाने वाला मार्ग" है। इसलिए यह कहना पर्याप्त होगा कि स्थानीय जनता के दिल में इस झील का विशेष स्थान है और हर हाइकर को यह सदा ध्यान में रखना चाहिए।
भौगोलिक दृष्टि से सतोपंथ झील ट्रैक मार्ग गढ़वाल क्षेत्र की सबसे सुंदर और सुखदायी ट्रेल में से एक है। झील चौखम्बा, नीलकंठ, और बालाकुन पर्वत शिखरों से घिरी हुई है। इस मार्ग में भारत का अंतिम गाँव माना, वसुंधरा, सहस्त्रधारा (जिसमें 100 से अधिक झरने हैं) जैसे आकर्षण देखे जा सकता है। अलकनंदा के तट पर ट्रेकिंग और लक्ष्मी वन और चक्रतीर्थ घास के मैदान में डेरा डालना भी इस ट्रैकिंग का सबसे अच्छा अनुभव है।

images.caption: हिमालय में पदयात्रा मार्ग: सतोपंथ ताल ट्रैक, उत्तराखंड, भारत
सतोपंथ ट्रैक का गंतव्य- शांत सतोपंथ ग्लेशियर झील, उत्तराखंड, भारत।

title: Alpspitz - Nesselwang - Day round trip
short_description:
From Nesselwang via the Alpspitz to Jungholz and back again. This beautiful day tour is easy to do with a medium level of fitness.
With small breaks, you should allow approx. 6-7 hours for the day tour. The total ascent is 1148m.
long_description: There are numerous opportunities to stop for refreshments along the way, such as at the Sportheim Böck on the Alpsitz or the Alpe Stubental in Jungholz (Österreich). On the hike, you can reach the next summit with mostly only small detours. So you can enjoy the view from the Kappelkamp (1482m), the Alpspitz (1575m), the Edelsberg (1630m) and, with only a small diversions, the Grad (1338m) into the foothills of the Alps. Here you can also replace the ascent to the Alpspitz with a train ride. For prices see: https://www.alpspitzbahn.de/preise.html .

images.caption: Auf dem Weg zur Alpe Stubental

title: Snowshoe hike to the Haglere summit
short_description: This snowshoe hike from the village of Sörenberg offers impressive views of the surrounding mountains. An ideal excursion for snow lovers and winter sports enthusiasts.
long_description: Start your short summit tour at terrain point 1159 in the village center of Sörenberg. From here, you ascend along the fall line to terrain point 1289. Then follow the summer hiking trail across the picturesque Alpweid and through open terrain to Mittlist Gfäl. You climb the next 200 vertical meters in a north-easterly direction and soon reach the Dählebode at 1805 m.a.s.l. You hike the last 150 vertical meters along the ridge in a south-easterly direction until you reach the Haglere, the highest point and also the destination of this tour. The descent takes place comfortably along the ascent route, allowing you to enjoy the beautiful view and fresh mountain air once again.

title: South Tyrol Sky Marathon - Percorso medio
short_description: Every year at the end of July during the Südtirol Ultra Skyrace event lots of extreme athletes run on this trailrunning route in South Tyrol. But of course, you can face this challenge also during the rest of the year.
long_description: Even the Marathon version of the Südtirol Ultra Sky race is a ripsnorter: 42 km and 2.863 m of ascent are the hard facts of this tour. After coming down from Totenkirchl you can celebrate your achievement in the centre of Sarentino.

title: Mule track
long_description:
The topographical situation of the town of Zug is characterised by its location on the lake and on the western slope of the Zugerberge. In the medieval settlement of Zug, the fishing trade was of great importance, which is also reflected in the name, which derives from old fishing rights on Lake Zug. The foundation of the town of Zug in the early 13th century under the Counts of Kyburg reflects Zug's growing function as a small regional centre. Zug am See became a transhipment point for goods and merchandise brought from the north across Lake Zurich to Horgen and from there to Zug via the old Horgen road Hirzel - Babenwag - Baar - Löberen. The goods transported were salt and iron. At various places along the lake in the old town and the suburbs, the goods were reloaded onto ships, which ensured the connection to Immensee and thus the connection via the "Hohle Gasse" to Küssnacht and Lake Lucerne. The numerous old buildings that still exist in the core area of the old Swiss Confederation, most of which have been severely alienated from their purpose, bear witness to medieval trade and transport policy.

Sights:

Land and waterways
Modern research has reconstructed many roads that date back to Roman times. In the Middle Ages, road construction was insignificant and the quality of land transport routes was often poor. The most important, safest and fastest transport route was water. In the old Confederation, too, waterways were made usable for transport as far as possible. Where traffic had to be routed over roads, the confederate towns had been trying to ensure safety on roads and paths through agreements with each other since the 14th century. In the Pfaffenbrief of 1370, the confederate states of Zurich, Lucerne, Uri, Schwyz, Unterwalden and Zug undertook to protect traffic on the Gotthard route. The condition and state of the overland routes always led to discussions among the partners.

Only a few road routes crossed what is now the canton of Zug. In addition to the central connection Horgen - Sihlbrugg - Baar - Zug, there was a road coming from Zurich and the Albis in the Knonau / Bibersee area that reached Zug soil and continued to Lucerne. A later connection branched off from Sihlbrugg in the direction of Hinterburg and led via Edlibach - Kohlrain into the Aegeri valley and from there along the Aegeri lake to Sattel and the Schwyz valley basin. Topographical conditions played a major role in the construction of paths and roads. Swampy terrain and difficult terrain prevented the construction of paths and roads. For this reason, the direct connection from Zug to Baar was not built through the plain until modern times, but along the hillside from Inwil via Arbach, Lüssi and Löberen into the town of Zug.

The old Horgen road
The course of the old Horgen road can be reconstructed on Zug soil roughly like this: From Babenwag, the road led past the customs site and the Löwen inn. Until the abolition of the cantonal road tolls, the Weber family from Menzingen served as customs officers and also ran the inn. From 1779 to 1805, Zoller Klemens Franz Xaver Damian Weber held the highest office in Zug at that time, that of bailiff, for four terms of office. Due to massive changes to the site and the building fabric, as well as the fire at the Löwen inn in Sihlbrugg in 1964, it has become very difficult today to recognise the original significance of the site. The next fixed point reached by the users of the mule track was Walterswil. Since 1610, the Cistercian monastery of Wettingen had gradually acquired several farms in the area and set a structural accent in 1692 with the construction of the Wettinger Haus. Around 1700, the Walterswil spa experienced its greatest heyday. Behind the Büessikon farm, the path led slightly downhill to the Breitholz forest.

Dangers in the Breitholz
Here the carters had to overcome the greatest difficulties. The slope was at times as steep as 15%. The construction of a firm and stable path proved to be almost impossible, as rainfall and the resulting landslides repeatedly caused the terrain to collapse. On the steep descent, the carts started to slide despite the brake racks or wheel hammers that had been attached, thus destroying the top layer of the surface and creating new tracks in the path bed. This resulted in an extensive system of hollow tracks in the Breitholz, comprising up to twelve tracks, which can still be recognised by the discerning eye to some extent today, although wood has grown over it since then. It also became critical when two or even more carts crossed each other in the Breitholz. Not infrequently this led to serious accidents. To make matters worse, highwaymen occasionally took advantage of the difficulties of the carters and stole some of the goods. The bottom of the valley was reached at the so-called Römerbrüggli in Deinikon, which crosses the Walterswilerbach. Past the hamlet of Deinikon, the mule track ran in the direction of the Birsen or Birst bridge. This structure, first mentioned in 1490, overcomes the Lorze. In the village of Baar, the carters could rest and eat. The path continued along the so-called Herrengasse to the hamlet of Inwil. Here a slight incline followed and past the hamlet of Arbach, the muleteers reached the area of the Lüssi neighbourhood in the city of Zug. At the Loreto Chapel, the mule track touched the site of the former place of execution before stately farmhouses and manor houses announced the nearby town. After 1528, the Löberentor (Löber Gate) brought the transports to a halt. The last stretch led the muleteers via Lindenplatz to the customs house near the Zitturm.

Rights and freedoms
In 1326 the Habsburg Duke Albrecht II granted the town of Zug the right to collect customs duties "an der bruggen ze Zuge". This customs duty, which was collected at the bridge over the moat to the town gate (customs house), had been created by Albrecht's brother, Duke Leopold I, who died in the same year. In 1359, Albrecht's son, Duke Rudolf IV of Habsburg, granted the people of Zug even more extensive rights. On the one hand, the previously formulated freedoms and rights, i.e. also the bridge toll of 1326, were fully confirmed, on the other hand, the town of Zug now received the right to establish a goods and merchants' depot, a Sust, and to use its revenues. Emperor Sigmund in 1433 and King Maximilian in 1488 renewed all rights, so that the town of Zug, which had become free of the Empire in 1415, was able to accumulate a certain wealth. This enabled the town's citizens to acquire a number of bailiwicks in several stages, which remained in municipal ownership until 1798.

Dispute over road ownership and maintenance
By virtue of its imperial freedom, the town of Zug claimed the right over ownership of the imperial road from Sihlbrugg to Zug, which resulted in a protracted dispute with the municipality of Baar. Baar was convinced that if Zug claimed ownership rights, it was also responsible for the maintenance of the Zug section of the imperial road. However, the council and citizens of Zug neglected this obligation, which led to repeated complaints about the poor condition of the road. In the Susten dispute of 1491, Zug complained to Zurich that various packers were avoiding customs in Zug by choosing an alternative route from Blickensdorf to Steinhausen, thus depriving the town of Zug of customs and excise revenues. In addition, these illegal transports caused great damage on the unimproved road. However, the city did not respond to Zurich's complaints about the poor condition of the Horgen imperial road, which continued after 1491, until the end of the 18th century, after Zurich and Schwyz had built a rival route with the Richterswil - Brunnen route. But the people of Zug had missed the right time to renovate and expand the old Horgenerstrasse on Baar territory. Political and, above all, drastic changes in the transport system massively reduced the importance of the mule track before1848, when the cantonal customs duties were abolished, the previously profiting communities were also deprived of an important source of income.

Transport
The evidence of the first wagon transports can be found in the customs, tax and duty regulations of 1435 and the customs regulations of 1488. Provisions on traffic over the mule track from Horgen to the Zug region can be found in a document of 1452, the wording of which was taken up again in later texts. According to this, merchants' goods arriving in Horgen were to be shipped on quickly. This concerned the so-called bound goods, such as goods in boxes, barrels, bales as well as wine and salt. The transport was assigned to a hemmer or hodler, who was responsible for packing the cargo according to the regulations. Anyone who owned a horse and was able to lift a hem was allowed to call himself a hemmer. The hemmer worked on behalf of other merchants for his own account. The hodler also found work in the medieval and early modern transport system. He acted as a middleman and hemmed on his own account. Special attention was paid to the transport of wine. As early as 1403, the estates of Zurich, Lucerne, Zug and Schwyz had agreed that wine was to be transported clean and pure. The main aim was to prevent muleteers and farmhands from feasting on the precious liquid during transport and filling the barrels with water to cover up the offence. However, this demand could not be enforced, so the partners involved later conceded to the muleteers and carters and those who helped with the loading to be allowed to taste the wine.

Collection of customs
Goods coming from Horgen were cleared in Zug at the customs house. The customs officer at the gate, as his office was called, had to inform the Sustmeister that the goods had already been cleared through customs, which corresponded to a receipt for the transport of goods. Conversely, the Sustmeister collected customs duty from those goods that were delivered via the lake. The existing accounts show that the revenues of the town customs were always higher than those of the Sustmeister, even if the transported quantity remained low compared to other towns.

Sources and literature:
Dändliker Paul / Schwegler Hans; Strassenbau und Verkehrsplanung im Kanton Zug, in: Zuger Neujahrsblatt 1973, p.91ff, Zug 1972.
Glauser Thomas, Sust und Zoll in der mittelalterlichen Stadt Zug, in: Tugium 16/2000, p.79-96, Zug 2000.
Gruber Eugen; Von der alten Baarer- oder Horgenerstrasse, in: Zeitschrift Landis & Gyr, Nr. 6, 1972, Zug 1972.
Grünenfelder Josef; Die Kunstdenkmäler des Kantons Zug. Neue Ausgabe I.
Das ehemalige Aeussere Amt. Hrsg. Gesellschaft für Schweizerische Kunstgeschichte (GSK) Bern, Basel 1999.
Schiedt Hans-Ulrich; Das Hohlwegsystem im Breitholz, in: Bulletin IVS 97/1, p.39 ff.
Urkundenbuch von Stadt und Amt Zug, 2 Volumes, Zug 1952.
Weber Anton; Die Sihl- oder Horgener-Strasse und die Sust in Zug. Ein Beitrag zum Handelsverkehr zwischen dem Zürichseegebiet und der Innerschweiz, in: Zuger Neujahrsblatt 1886, Zug 1885.
Zollinger Jakob; Die "Säumerstrasse von Horgen nach Zug, in: Blätter der Vereinigung Pro Sihltal, Nr.14, 1964.

Stadtarchiv Zug / Zug Tourismus, April 2010

title: Amorbach-Laudenberg
long_description:
Author
Günter Frömbgen
Update: September 16, 2015

title: Snowshoe hike from Schüpfheim to Hasle
short_description: This snowshoe hike in the heart of the UNESCO Biosphere Entlebuch offers the perfect mix of winter adventure, impressive scenery and sporting challenge.
long_description:
Start your tour in the center of Schüpfheim and follow the summer hiking trail in a south-easterly direction up to Stolen. The ascent rewards you with picturesque views of the valley. Shortly afterwards, turn north-east and cross the idyllic Reisteggwald forest before reaching the gem of Heiligkreuz. From there, you follow the hiking trail further east and reach Schwarzenbergchrüz, a magnificent vantage point.
You then hike around the charming Hornbüelchnubel, which impresses with its tranquil atmosphere, and reach Vorderschwändi. The trail continues along the road to Gruebehag. Here you leave the road and walk north along the picturesque path to Schlund. There you change direction to the west and descend via Bärgli to finally reach the end of your tour in Hasle.
This varied hike offers a successful mix of forest paths, panoramic views and peaceful alpine meadows.

images.caption: Snowshoe tour in the UNESCO Biosphere Entlebuch

title: नैीताल में किलबरी हिमालय दर्शन ट्रैक
short_description: यह ट्रैक किलबरी रोड के किनारे मौजूद हिमालय दर्शन अवलोकन बिंदु तक जाता है जहा ँ से हिमालय की बर्फ से ढकी चोटियों के पैनोरैमिक नज़ारें और नैनीताल शहर का मनोरम दृश्य दिखते हैं।
long_description:
हिमालय दर्शन एक अवलोकन बिंदु है जो इको गार्डन से करीब 8 किलोमीटर दूर नैनीताल-किलबरी रोड के किनारे मौजूद है। आम तौर पर यह एक पारम्परिक ट्रैक मार्ग तो नहीं है क्योंकि यहाँ तक का पूरा रास्ता असल में एक पक्की सड़क है लेकिन फिर भी कम ट्रैफिक वाली सड़क होने की वजह से हाइकर्स यहाँ आना पसंद करते हैं। आसपास के गाँव के लोग भी नैनीताल आने के बाद इसी मार्ग द्वारा अक्सर पैदल अपने गाँवों को वापस जाते हैं।
यह मार्ग हरियाली से भरा हुआ है और पक्की सड़क होने के बावजूद बहुत कम गाड़ियां यहाँ आती हैं। रास्ते के दोनों तरफ पेड़ और घास मौजूद रहती है। शौकिया घुमक्कड़, स्थानीय स्कूल/कॉलेज के छात्र, और पर्यटक भी कभी कभार इस मार्ग में दिखते हैं। इस ट्रैक का कठिनाई स्तर सामान्य है और इसको करने के लिए कुछ ख़ास उपकरण नहीं चाहिए। रास्ता ठंडा और पहाड़ी मोड़ों से भरा हुआ है। ट्रैक के लिए घोड़े और दूरबीन भी किराए पर मिलते है। अंतिम गंतव्य पर चाय नाश्ते के कुछ छोटे स्टाल भी मौजूद हैं ताकि चाय की गरम गरम चुस्कियों के साथ ठंडी बर्फीली चोटियों का मजा लिया जा सके।

images.caption: हिमालय में पदयात्रा मार्ग: नैनीताल में किलबरी हिमालय दर्शन ट्रैक

title: Snowshoe hike from Wasen to Luthern
short_description: This easy hike is perfect for anyone looking for a winter excursion with snowshoes in the canton of Lucerne. Enjoy the snow-covered paths and the tranquillity of winter nature.
long_description:
You start your snowshoe hike from Stägmatt near Wasen i.E. and first walk in a north-easterly direction to Gitzichnübeli. Enjoy the gentle ascent and the wintry landscape around you. From there, follow the summer hiking trail further north-east to Hornachegg and cross the dense forest in an easterly direction to Fritzeflue and finally to Ahorn. Here you change direction to the southeast and soon reach the highest point of your hike, from where you have an impressive view of the surrounding mountains. Continue along the summer hiking trail over open, snow-covered terrain to Chatzerschwand. The descent then takes you down to Luthern, past the idyllic hamlets of Birbaum and Farnegg, accompanied by picturesque views of the landscape.

Note(s)
- Long ridge hike on summer hiking trails
- Follow the signposts

images.caption: Snowshoe hikers in the powder snow

title: Münster round trip
long_description:
The starting point of this short, marked beginner's tour is in the north-eastern edge of the village of Münster. At the beginning, you climb 100 metres in altitude to Löumene and have thus already reached the highest point of this short circular tour. Then hike in a north-easterly direction through the Birchwald forest until you reach Gaschinen. Continue hiking below the ski lift and then climb again a few metres in a westerly direction to reach Münster, the starting point of the tour.

Note(s)
- Marked beginner's tour

title: Cristallina
long_description:
From Ossasco, start hiking in a southerly direction through the Bosco dei Piei and along the Cristallina stream to the Alpe di Cristallina. Still following the same direction, you cross the Cristallinaalp and finally reach the Val Torta. Hiking through it, you turn southwest and soon reach the Passo di Cristallina. If you haven't had enough yet, you can tackle the challenging section on the Cristallina and will then be rewarded with a breathtaking view.
The descent follows the ascent route.

Note(s)
- Avalanche knowledge, alpine technical knowledge and sufficient fitness are required
- Ascent to the hut evenly. Approach to the Cristallina technically demanding
- If possible, follow existing tracks

.

title: A trip to the Partnachklamm gorge
short_description: A relatively short and easy walking route in the Partnach-Klamm gorge near the town of Garmisch.
long_description: An easy walking route in the Partnach-Klamm gorge. The route includes walking through a number of tunnels carved into the rock and is full of breathtaking views and turquoise waters flowing in the stream. The route marked on the map is linear and suitable for walking with strollers since the roads are relatively wide and paved (the road leading to the gorge is a gravel road that may be muddy after rains). You can also make a circular trip there and pass through an authentic Bavarian cabin (not accessible for strollers) or return back the same way. Most of the route is on a plain, while at one point there is a short but not particularly difficult slope.

title: The Cougoir by the ridges from Teyssières
short_description: Beautiful hike from the village of Teyssières which takes the paths located on the heights of the Cougoir ravine! Very nice views of the landscapes of the Baronnies provençales, and in particular of the lavender fields in June and July ;)
long_description:
At the start, we reach the Col de Venterol and the Pas de la Pousterle allows us to climb the Cougoir by the South ridge. Then, the small wild path of the Sauveginoux mountain offers a beautiful view of the mountain pastures of the Croix.
.

title: Panorama Ridge - Stunning Panoramic View
short_description: The views from Panorama Ridge are one of the most scenic views in the Garibaldi Provincial Park.
long_description: Beautiful and rewarding hike to Panorama Ridge. Stunning lakes, impressive trees and wildlife along the track. It is possible to hike up to Taylor Meadows and stay there for a couple of nights, so you can even do the Black Tusk trail too. Many hikers will do this in a day, but keep in mind to retun during daylight hours.

title: Piz dErr
long_description:
The starting point of this two-day tour is Spinas, west of Bever. From Alp Spinas you hike the first 12 kilometres along the Beverin through the Val Bever. Then a short ascent takes you to the Jenatsch Hut, where you spend the night. The next day you hike about 700 metres up to Piz dErr. First you pass the "Vadret dErr" glacier and finally reach the foot of Piz dErr via a saddle between Piz dErr and Corn Jenatsch. Via the north-eastern ridge you finally reach the top of Piz dErr. For the descent, follow the ascent route again.

Note(s)
- Before the tour, analyse the current avalanche bulletin!
- The tour requires sufficient physical condition.
- Pay attention to the game rest zones!

title: The Parisians: Concorde, Tuileries, Louvre, Orsay, Assemblée Nationale
short_description: From the Place de la Concorde to the National Assembly, a short escapade in the Paris of lights.
long_description:
This short walk, accessible to all, proposes to discover some of the most emblematic buildings of Paris.
From the Place de Concorde, where the Luxor Obelisk has been enthroned since 1836, to the National Assembly, via the Jardin des Tuileries, the oldest of the capital's French gardens, the Louvre and its pyramid, the Pont des Arts and the Musée d'Orsay, you will be able to appreciate some of the sites that make Paris, a city like no other.

title: Ganztageswanderung von Sonkajärvi nach Hyrynsalmi über Kajaani, Sotkamo und Paltamo am 11. Dezember 2024

title: On the King Hübich Route in Bad Grund
short_description: Seeing points along the route from the Hübichenstein to the Grüne Tanne are the HöhlenErlebnisZentrum with stalactite cave and the Knesebeck mine.
long_description: The snowshoe hike on the King Hübich Route begins at the foot of the limestone rock Hübichenstein. After about 1.5 km we reach the Iberg Dripstone Cave with the Cave Experience Centre. It is many millions of years old and is one of the most famous sights in the Harz Mountains. A guided tour with a wealth of information on its history is a must. The Knesebeck mine is also located in Bad Grund. The adjoining mining museum provides insights into the history of the listed site.

images.caption: Illumination Lagune in der Iberger Tropfsteinhöhle im HöhlenErlebnisZentrum

title: Büelenhorn
long_description: Fantastic tour with magnificent views of the snow-covered winter landscape. From Monstein you hike leisurely to Inneralp and on to Mäschenboden. In a large curve you climb steeply up via Büelen to the Büelenhorn. You can easily find your way back to the starting point via the ascent route.

short_description: On foot to the Oy valley and back again by scooter
long_description: The beautiful, family-friendly tour runs along rivers most of the time.

title: Great Raven's Peak (Pic du Grand Corbeau)
short_description: This 154 km² national park is dominated by the highest peak in the region, Mount Valin, at an altitude of 980 m. Its territory is covered by mixed and boreal forests, dotted with 125 bodies of water. These include five rivers with rapids and waterfalls, including the Valin River, the largest
long_description: The Pic-de-la-Hutte trail leads to the summit of the peak of the same name, at an altitude of 900 m, from where you will have a panoramic view of the city of Saguenay and, on a clear day, the edge of Lac Saint-Jean. The difficult climate marked the vegetation of this summit. There are smaller trees, arctic-alpine plants and lichens. The Pic-de-la-Tête-de-Chien trail passes through rocky plateaus and offers a view of the Valin River. Pic-du-Grand-Corbeau is for more experienced hikers. It climbs the mountain and offers a view of its escarpments. The La Randonnée des Pics trail, a long hiking trail, crosses the entire territory of the Park, from the Discovery and Service Centre to Lake Martin-Valin. The route is done in one to three nights, leaving the choice to the hikers for the duration of their adventure. The Park offers a shuttle bus and luggage transport to facilitate travel.

images.caption: hiking trail in Québec: Great Raven's Peak (Pic du Grand Corbeau)

title: Kust till Kustleden - from Gryteskär to Ängelholm
short_description: The last stage of the Kust till Kustledens leads from the Gryteskär campsite north of the village of Vejbystrand üalong a flat coastal path to Ängelholm railway station.
long_description: Kust till Kustleden ends in Ängelholm. After about 280 km of walking, we can enjoy a well-deserved rest here. Ängelholm was originally founded closer to the beach, but had to be relocated due to migrating diners. Today, the Kronoskogen forest provides a protective barrier.

title: Stone Age People and Water Mills in Wallhalben
short_description: Along the Wallhalb and the Odenbach we pass some mills during this hike, discover the world of the Stone Age people and the water show trail.
long_description:
There is a lot to discover around Wallhalben: We start with the dwelling place of the Stone Age people, which lies between Rosendorf and Kneispermühle. Albert Westrich from Schmitshausen found this site about 25 years ago during excavations. The exact background can be read on an information board.
Back on our path, we can enjoy beautiful views of the Sickinger Höhe before arriving at the Kneispermühle. The mill, which dates from 1440, was destroyed in the Thirty Years' War and rebuilt in 1701. In order to have sufficient driving water even in times of drought, the Wallhalb was dammed up in front of the Kneispermühle to form a larger pond, a Woog, which is still preserved today. The large horse chestnut trees offer the guests of the pub sufficient shade in summer. This is our first opportunity to stop for refreshments.
The second follows shortly afterwards at the Weihermühle, before we reach the Wasserschaupfad along the Odenbach. This facility was built in 1978 and is the first of its kind in the Palatinate. The panels along the way provide information about the formation of the Odenbach valley. The Odenbach itself took a million years to carve out this valley. Along the way, you can marvel at numerous rock formations and waterfalls.

title: Senda de Litoral - The complete route along the Santander coast
short_description: A route that has become a Sunday stroll or siesta for the locals, so it can't be missing from your list of activities if you are on holiday in Santander, whatever the season.
long_description:
The route has an urban part, a coastal part, and a coastal part only.
Start with the oldest areas of the city - the fishing district and the promenade of Santander harbour. You climb to the beach area, the most elegant in the city, the place that swarms with tourists in summer. Santander has several beaches and you'll pass by them all - Los Peligros, Magdalena, Los Bikinis, El Camello, Sardinero I, Sardinero II, Los Molinucos, Las Matales. Beyond that, you'll tick off La Maruca or Virgen del Mar beaches towards the end.
The coastal and footpath part of the route & in the true sense of the word & starts beyond the Cabo Mayor lighthouse. The path goes over the cliffs, up and down the dome, reaches the English Pantheon, and continues to La Maruca. After the memorial, the route has few signs of habitation and you can see local people walking their horses.
Between La Maruca and Virgen del Mar beach, the scenery changes a little, going further inland along the coast, over farmland and along the coast that is cultivated throughout the year.

title: Orekhovsky waterfall (Sochi)
short_description: Orekhovsky Falls is not only one of the highest waterfalls in the Sochi area, but also one of the closest and most accessible.
long_description: For a break from the hustle and bustle of Sochi, you can take a hike to Orekhovsky Waterfall. The Orekhovsky Falls are located to the east of the village of Orekhovka, approximately one kilometre away. Such a holiday at the waterfall will encourage you to return to the city and start thinking about your next outdoor adventures.

title: Walk along the Weiler Ach
short_description: Beautiful round to relax
long_description: After parking at the tunnel in Obermaiselstein, we follow the tarred road to Bolsterlang. From here we follow beautiful footpaths to Obermühlegg and further to Weiler Ach. Along this we return to the starting point.

images.caption: Hiking in the Allgäu: Walk along the Weiler Ach river

title: To the Altenburg with a view of Bamberg
short_description: Starting in the Babenberger Viertel, we visit the Altenburg in Bamberg. The most beautiful part of the tour runs through the forest along the Altenburger Weg.
long_description:
The Altenburg looks beautiful in any weather. As the castle is located on a hill, it can be seen from many locations in the city. In the dark, the castle is illuminated with traditional lighting s. And when the basketball team „Brose Basket“ is playing, the lighting is changed to pink.
Until about 40 years ago, Poldi the brown bear, Germany's last Burgbär, lived in the Altenburg. Today, he can only be seen in a photo at his former castle. Interesting, isn't it?

title: Small Kempten Round
short_description: Small circular route through the meadows and forests of Kempten's south, with the Nordic walking poles, jogging or as a walk.
long_description: The starting point of the tour is in the south of Kempten, in beautiful Adelharz. From the hikers' car park, walk along the Adelharzer Weg in the direction of Kempten. After about 400 m, we turn left onto the meadow path, where we turn left after a further 600 m. We then turn right onto the path. When we reach its end, we keep left to get onto the Steinbergweg. After a small climb, we take the first turn to the left and follow the Steinbergweg until we reach a farm. There, a path between the cowshed and the animal enclosure leads us directly into the Adelharz forest. Once there, we follow the gravel path in the direction of the Vorarlberg graves. From there we follow the forest path to get back to the starting point.

title: Estartit - the green canals of the coast
short_description: Beautiful easy hike through pine homes and rocky coastal zones with swimming opportunities at beautiful bays.
long_description:
This beautiful walking area is located just outside Estartit and is within walking distance of the town centre. The outward route of the tour leads through hilly wooded areas, which allows beautiful views of the bay of Rosas. You reach the first bathing place, the lonely bay of Cala de Ferriol, after about 2 hours. Now you continue over rocky terrain close to the coast to the second bay, Cala de Pedrosa. Here you should definitely take a dip in the clean water. The 60-minute return begins with a crisp climb over a mini-trail that leads over stones and sand. We find our way back to Estartit through pine homes and, at the end, the descent via an asphalt road that is not frequented.
The peace and quiet during the tour is only pleasantly "disturbed" by loudly chirping insects.

images.caption: View of the hiking area and the bay of Rosas

title: 12h Mountain Experience Watzmann 2019 - Biolectra 24h Trophy
short_description: In 2019 the Watzmann was the focus of the "Biolectra 24h Trophy". Designed for beginners, this 12-hour hike led from Berchtesgaden up to the Watzmannhaus and back.
long_description:
The "Biolectra 24h Trophy" is the largest event series in the field of long-distance hiking. Regularly organised 12h and 24h hikes take place in selected hiking regions in Europe. The core idea is not competition, but the shared hiking experience. The routes are designed to hike the numerous cultural and scenic highlights of the respective region.
In 2019, the event made a guest appearance in Berchtesgadener Land. At the centre of the various hikes was the 2713 m high Watzmann. However, not all routes led to the summit: the 12h variant described here is suitable for anyone new to the sport of long-distance hiking. It leads from Berchtesgaden to the Watzmannhaus at 1930 m and back again.

title: Small mountain near the town of Santander - Peña Cabarga
short_description: Just as Tâmpa is a mountain for Brasov, Pe a Cabarga is a mountain for the people of Santander and the inhabitants of the small towns near Santander Bay. And one with a greater difference in level than the mountain of Brasov!
long_description:
Pico Len Peak (569 metres), the highest peak in the Peñada Cabarga Park, is easily seen from all around due to the tower in the summit.
The shape of the tower has also earned it a nickname - Monumento al Indiano - so some trail descriptions may mention the peak under this name.
The Astillero route starts on asphalt, just outside the town, which is an opportunity to see a glimpse of rural life in this part of Cantabria. Then on a cobbled path, and for the last few hundred metres, on a dirt track. It climbs steeper at the start and finish, so it's good to dose your energy. The trail is poorly marked and intersects with many other options that cross the mountain or form a flat circuit to the summit; this route is the most direct and quickest route, though.
Moreover, some trails seem overgrown and rarely trodden by hikers. And yet, following just one of these, on the descent, we entered a small troical forest (at least that was the feeling there, in the middle of a tangle of mosses, trees with thinned trunks and green stumps).

images.caption: On the last few hundred metres of asphalt, still in Astillero
Almost tropical vegetation on some stretches
Just a little further and we're at the top
Panoramic view of the bay and city of Santander

title: San Juan Scenic Skyway
short_description: This round trip makes you discover the beautiful and pristine lansdcape of Colorado, the highest state of the USA.  On its 233 miles you get to see several hidden treasures of the stunning San Juan Mountains.
long_description:
San Juan Scenic Skyway is a breathtaking scenic route of 233 miles leading through the  Centennial State. It owes its name to the impressive San Juan Mountains, a vast mountain range covering a huge fraction of San Juan National Forest.
Departing in the city of Durango in the midst of the Four Corners, where the states of Colorado, Utah, Arizona and New Mexico meet. The route develops through several traditional mining towns and pristine mountain areas. Heading north towards Uncompahgre National Forest we get to see dense woodlands and pretty rivers before we turn east along Million Dollar Highway taking in an almost desert-like scenery. Getting back to Durango we drive through From Red Mountain Pass, a picturesque mountain saddle between Uncompahgre National Forest and San Juan National Forest.

images.caption: Panoramablick vom San Juan Scenic Skyway
View of Durango from Rim Drive

title: Cologne Trail - once around the metropolis on the Rhine
short_description: Despite the fact that we are directly in the urban area of Cologne, we walk most of the time in the middle of nature and still experience the cultural and historical diversity of the city.
long_description:
This circular walk is divided into 11 stages (see below) and takes us once around the outer districts of the Rhine metropolis. Each stage can be easily reached by public transport and can be shortened or extended as desired. The idea behind the trail is not only to invite you to walk in the region, but also to make you aware of the many facets of the urban centre. Therefore, information boards point out cultural sights, historical sites, interesting attractions, rest areas, parks, playgrounds and places to stop for refreshments. Another special feature is the prominent sponsorships for the individual stages. For example, the hiking book author and well-known editor Manuel Andrack has taken on the sponsorship for the third stage of the day.
We start our hike in the south of Cologne at the Rodenkirchener Brücke bridge and follow the Weißen Rheinbogen. Shortly before Weiß, we leave the river and head south of Roden-Kirchen to the Forstbotanischer Garten. Now we walk north through the outer Cologne green belt. Passing the clubhouse of the 1.FC Köln and the Adenauerweiher, we continue to the Belvedere Landscape Park and the Nüssenberger Busch. Between Pesch, Auweiler and Esch we walk leisurely along the banks of several small lakes. We continue our way through the Escher Holz, reach the Worringer Bruch and then follow the Rhine for a short distance in a southerly direction. After a wide curve to the Fühlinger Seen lakes, we cross the river on the Mülheimer Brücke bridge. Like a green ribbon, several forests criss-cross the urban area between Cologne and Bergisch-Gladbach - giving us perfect hiking pleasure. Passing the Bensberg Lake, we embark on a long loop. We pass Lerbach Castle and reach the highest point of the Kölnpfad at Breite, which offers us a magnificent panoramic view. We will see that it is worth leaving the Cologne city area for a short while for this. Through the Hardter Wald forest and the village of Bensberg, we reach the Königsforst, which lives up to its name: we walk for several kilometres under shady trees, past small ponds and across bubbling streams. Behind Wahn, we walk between fields and meadows back to the Rhine and follow its long windings to the Rodenkirchener Brücke bridge, from where we started.
Stage 1: Rodenkirchener Rheinbrücke - Klettenberg (22 km)
Stage 2: Klettenberg - Bocklemünd (18 km)
Stage 3: Bocklemünd - Roggendorf/Thenhoven (16 km)
Stage 4: Roggendorf/Thenhoven - Merkenich (11 km)
Stage 5: Merkenich - Wiener Platz (13 km)

title: Between Waterfalls in the Serra da Bocaina - Gold Trail
short_description: Second part of the Gold Trail that follows a stretch from the Posses Waterfall to the incredible Veados Waterfall with its impressive 200 meters high.
long_description: The Gold Trail in the Serra da Bocaina National Park, é one of the most traditional mountain walks in Brazil. Situated between Rio de Janeiro and São Paulo, this walk é long and challenging, but at the same time not so demanding.  The route é done in 3 days and starts at the entrance of the Bocaina National Park and follows through the preserved Atlantic Forest of the Serra da Bocaina and Mar, until é Mambucaba, in Angra dos Reis. It takes about 6 hours of walking a day and there are several natural and cultural attractions. <The second leg of the Gold Trail begins at Posses Waterfall, which has an incredible natural pool with a clean water mirror, ideal for refreshing swim. Further ahead we find first time path old original trail in its íute;nte. After stretch closed forest, you reach Veados considered most beautiful waterfall all Bocaína, three main falls total height 200m.
